Developing a stable and effective Ni-based catalyst for low-temperature CO2 methanation remains a significant challenge. This study presents the synthesis of a range of MgO-promoted Ni-based catalysts supported on natural halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) through a sol-gel method assisted by citric acid. At 275°C, Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA exhibits the highest CO2 conversion (88.5%) and CH4 selectivity (98.4%). The sufficient basic sites and Ni0 sites of Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0CA are beneficial for CO2 activation and H2 dissociation, leading to high activity at low temperatures. Additionally, Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA exhibits better anti-sintering ability during 100 h reaction, attributed to the increased interaction between metal and support. The in-situ DRIFTS results show that Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA mainly follows both formate and CO pathways, and the rapid transformation of intermediates causes superior catalytic performance. This work offers a rational design of stable and active catalysts for low-temperature CO2 methanation. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 methanation Sol-gel method Citric acid Ni-based catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The sustained combustion of fossil fuels has escalated atmospheric carbon dioxide levels, primarily contributing to global warming and extreme climate [1]. In light of heightened environmental awareness and the diminishing availability of primary energy sources, CO2 utilization technology has attracted extensive attention around the world [2,3]. Utilizing green hydrogen derived from renewable energy sources to transform CO2 into valuable chemicals or fuels (including methane, methanol, formic acid, olefins, and so on) is recognized as a highly effective strategy for mitigating CO2 emissions and attaining carbon neutrality [4,5]. Interestingly, the CO2 methanation reaction also referred to as the Sabatier reaction, can demonstrate high CH4 selectivity and an equilibrium CO2 conversion exceeding 90% even at low temperatures and atmospheric pressure [6,7]. Briefly, CO2 methanation shows greater potential advantages in industrial applications compared with other CO2 hydrogenation reactions. Since CO2 methanation is an exothermic process ( C O 2 + H 2 ↔ C H 4 + H 2 O , Δ H = − 165 kJ / mol ), low temperature is more favorable for its occurrence [8]. Nevertheless, many studies have shown that the actual temperature of CO2 methanation is usually higher than 350°C [9]. This may be because CO2 requires high temperatures for its σ and π bonds to activate and break due to its chemically inert. However, the relatively high temperature increases the energy consumption and promotes the reverse water gas reaction (RWGS: C O 2 + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O ), leading to an increase in the selectivity of the byproduct CO [10]. Additionally, high temperatures will cause the active phase to sinter, leading to the deactivation of the catalysts. Consequently, investigating a Ni-based catalyst that operates effectively at low temperatures for CO2 methanation remains a key objective in the current research. Various metal catalysts (Ru, Rh, Co, Fe, Ni, and so on) have been widely used in CO2 methanation reaction and have demonstrated excellent catalytic performance [11–15]. Among these, Ni-based catalysts are thought to be the most promising methanation catalysts due to their outstanding activity, selectivity, and cost-effectiveness [16]. Many strategies have been proposed to improve the catalytic performance of Ni-based catalysts at low temperatures, including novel supports [17,18], introducing promoters [19–21], and modifying preparation methods [22,23]. Typically, the preparation method can affect the metal-support interaction and the dispersion of metal particles, which in turn influences the catalytic performance [24]. So far, the impregnation method has been widely adopted due to its straightforward operation and cost-effectiveness. Nevertheless, the dispersion of metal particles prepared by the conventional impregnation method is generally low. Furthermore, the weak interaction between the active phase and the support makes the nanoparticles prone to agglomeration at high temperatures, thereby reducing the catalytic activity and stability [25]. To solve this problem, different preparation methods such as precipitation, sol-gel, hydrothermal, and plasma have been studied [26–29]. Importantly, the sol-gel method assisted with citric acid is a simple and low-cost synthesis process that has been proven to be an effective strategy for preparing highly dispersed metal nanoparticles [1,30,31]. The carboxyl group (COO−) in citric acid chelates with metal ions to form a complex, and forms a stable three-dimensional network structure through polymerizing, allowing metal ions to be evenly and stably dispersed on the catalyst surface [32]. Ye et al. [30] found that Ni particles in the Ni/CeO2-SGM prepared by a simple sol-gel method were highly dispersed, resulting in the maximized Ni-CeO2 interface. The CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity can reach 80.5% and 95.8% respectively even at 250°C. Moreover, Ni particles are embedded in CeO2, and the strong interaction prevents Ni/CeO2-SGM from deactivating during the 100 h long-term reaction. Wang et al. [33] reported that preparing Ni-La2O3/SBA-15 catalyst through the citric acid complexing sol-gel method can enhance the synergistic effect between La2O3 and Ni, resulting in finer metal particles as well as excellent anti-sintering and anti-carbon abilities. On the other hand, the support can also significantly influence the performance of the catalysts, typically by modulating the metal-support interaction and the dispersion of metal particles [34,35]. Halloysite nanotubes (HNTs, Al2(OH)4Si2O⋅nH2O), a natural aluminosilicate material have gained increasing attention in catalytic applications due to their porous structure, surface modifiability, and environmental compatibility [36,37]. In previous research [38], Ni-based catalysts prepared via an impregnation method using HNTs as support demonstrated excellent performance in CO2 methanation due to the small Ni particles and the sufficient basic sites for CO2 activation. However, improvements in the metal-support interaction are required to further enhance CO2 conversion at low temperatures and to improve the anti-sintering properties of catalysts. In this study, a range of Ni-Mg bimetallic catalysts supported on the natural halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) were synthesized through a sol-gel method assisted with citric acid, and the molar ratio of citric acid to metal ions was discussed in detail. The findings show that preparing catalysts with the sol-gel method can enhance the metal-support interaction, leading to a uniform and stable distribution of Ni particles. Furthermore, the molar ratio of citric acid/metal ions will affect the physical property and calcination process of the catalyst precursors, which in turn impacts the structure and performance of the catalysts. The physicochemical properties of the catalyst precursors and related catalysts were investigated by FT-IR, TG-DSC, XRD, TEM, XPS, CO2-TPD, and other characterization methods. Furthermore, the in-situ DRIFTS technique was also applied to observe the evolution of reaction intermediates, and the reaction mechanism can be speculated. Overall, this work offers a viable approach for preparing efficient Ni-based CO2 methanation catalysts applied at low temperatures. 2 Experimental sections 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts were synthesized by the citric acid-assisted sol-gel method, where x denotes the molar ratio of citric acid to metal ions, with x values of 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5 respectively. The specific synthesis process is shown in Scheme 1. In this work, Ni and Mg content in all the catalysts were fixed at 20wt% and 1.0wt%, respectively. Taking Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA catalyst as an example, the specific steps were as follows: First, 2.2578 g of Ni(NO3)2•6H2O and 0.2433 g of Mg(NO3)2•6H2O were dissolved in 30 mL of deionized water. After ultrasonic dispersion for 10 min, a specified quantity of citric acid was introduced, maintaining a molar ratio of citric acid to metal ions at 1.0. Subsequently, 1.8 g of halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) was added into the solution and stirred at room temperature for 1 hour. The solution was then transferred to a water bath at 80°C to facilitate the water evaporation. The resultant sample was dried in an oven at 80°C overnight and subsequently calcined in a muffle furnace at 550°C for 5 hours with a heating rate of 2°C/min to obtain the final catalyst. The synthesis procedures for Ni-Mg/HNTs-0.5 CA and Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.5 CA were identical to the aforementioned method, except for changing the molar ratio of citric acid/metal ions into 0.5 and 1.5, respectively. The contrasting example Ni-Mg/HNTs catalyst was prepared through a traditional impregnation method without adding citric acid. 2.2 Characterizations Characterization techniques and detailed procedures employed in this study are documented in the Supporting Information file. 2.3 Procedure of activity test The catalyst activity was assessed in a micro fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 6 mm under atmospheric pressure. The experimental procedure was as follows: First, about 480 mg of fresh catalyst was placed in the central section of the reaction tube, which was flanked by quartz sand for rapid heat conduction. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was reduced in a hydrogen stream (30 mL/min) at 500°C for 2 hours, followed by cooling to the initial reaction temperature under a N2 atmosphere. Finally, the gas flow was switched to the reaction mixture (the molar ratio of H2/CO2/N2=5/1/1) to start the reaction. The reaction products were separated by condensation and then analyzed online using a gas chromatography (GC 7900) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a flame sample detector (FID) to determine their specific composition and content. The CO2 methanation reaction was performed at temperatures ranging from 200 to 375°C in 25°C increments, with a space velocity maintained at 15,000 mL/g/h. The CO2 conversion ( X C O 2 ) and CH4 selectivity ( S C H 4 )were calculated according to the following relevant equations: (1) X C O 2 ( % ) = C C O 2 , in − C C O 2 , out C C O 2 , in × 100 (2) S C H 4 ( % ) = C C H 4 , out C C O 2 , in − C C O 2 , out × 100 % where C i , in and C i , out represented the concentration of substance i in the inlet and outlet streams, respectively. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Properties of catalyst precursors FT-IR characterization was used to explore the impact of citric acid on the surface groups of the catalyst precursors, which were not calcined. As presented in Fig. 1 , for the Ni-Mg/HNTs precursor, the peak appearing at 1386 cm−1 after loading metal Ni can be attributed to NO3 2−. The sharp peaks located around 3395 cm−1 and 1621 cm−1 are indicative of free water adsorbed on the surface [39]. On the contrary, for the precursors of Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA, the sharp peaks at 3395 cm−1 have disappeared and larger broad peaks are formed between 3580-2500 cm−1. This may be because citric acid complexes with metal ions, thus generating intermolecular hydrogen bonds. Meanwhile, the vibration peaks near 1628 cm−1 can also verify the generation of citric acid chelates [40]. The peaks appearing around 1725 cm−1 can be associated with the C=O stretching vibration peak of the carboxyl group in the citric acid. Interestingly, the intensity peak near 1725 cm−1 increases as the molar ratio of citric acid/metal ions increases, especially in the Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA and Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.5 CA precursors, indicating the existence of free carboxyl groups. The peak at 1725 cm−1 is almost invisible in the Ni-Mg/HNTs-0.5 CA precursors. The precursors of catalysts were further characterized by TG-DSC to analyze the decomposition process during calcination. For the precursor of Ni-Mg/HNTs Fig. 2(a ), the weight loss observed below 150°C can be assigned to the removal of free water and bound water. The weight loss between 150-250°C is caused by the decomposition of some metal nitrates. Moreover, due to a large number of metal nitrates breaking down, a large weight loss occurs at 250-350°C [41]. The last small weight loss between 350 and 500°C can be ascribed to the decomposition of residual metal nitrates [40]. Notably, three endothermic peaks appear at 160.7°C, 271.9°C, and 462.7°C respectively, implying that Ni-Mg/HNTs precursor requires heat during the calcination. Nevertheless, the decomposition of catalyst precursors prepared by the citric acid-assisted sol-gel method is mainly an exothermic process. This may be because citric acid will release heat when it breaks down. Additionally, the citric acid-metal complex can undergo an oxidation-reduction reaction with NO3 2−, thus providing heat for the decomposition of the precursors. The decomposition process of Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA precursors is shown in Fig. 2(b–d). At temperatures below 150°C, the removal of free and bound water from the precursors mainly occurs. And the large weight loss between 150 and 250°C can be attributed to the initial decomposition and spontaneous combustion of the free carboxyl groups in the citric acid and part of the citric acid-metal complexes. The weight loss between 250 and 400°C is mainly due to further oxidative decomposition of the complexes. Notably, the temperature and exothermic value of Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA precursors at this stage increase dramatically, indicating that the formed citric acid-metal complexes are more stable with the increasing molar ratio of citric acid/metal ions. However, releasing too much heat may cause metal particles to agglomerate during the calcination process. The slow weight loss between 400-500°C can be attributed to the further oxidative decomposition of organic residues. In particular, only Ni-Mg/HNTs-0.5 CA shows a smaller endothermic peak at this stage due to the presence of free metal nitrates caused by insufficient citric acid. 3.2 Structure and morphology of catalysts Fig. 3 presents the XRD patterns of the as-reduced catalysts. The peaks centered around 2θ=44.3°, 51.6°, and 76.1° can be attributed to the characteristic diffraction peaks of Ni(111), Ni(200), and Ni(220) respectively [42]. Additionally, the characteristic diffraction peaks of NiO or MgO are also observed near 2θ=37.4°, 43.4°, and 62.9°. Since the characteristic diffraction peaks of NiO and MgO are relatively close, it is difficult to distinguish. The appearance of Ni2+ may be due to the rapid oxidation of smaller Ni particles when exposed to the air, or due to the presence of NiO species that are difficult to reduce [43]. Notably, the peak intensity of the Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts is significantly reduced compared to Ni-Mg/HNTs, meaning that highly dispersed metal particles can be obtained through a simple sol-gel method assisted with citric acid. As shown in Fig. 3, the characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ=44.3° and 43.4° are overlapping. In order to reduce the calculation error, the average size of Ni particles was calculated using the Debye-Scherrer equation at 2θ=51.6°. With the increasing molar ratio of citric acid/metal ions, the mean size of Ni particles first decreases from 11.2 nm (Ni-Mg/HNTs) to 5.7 nm (Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA) and then increases to 6.4 nm (Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.5 CA), as listed in Table 1 . This may be because too much citric acid causes the release of excessive heat during the calcination process and prevents further refinement of metal particles. N2 isothermal adsorption and desorption experiments were performed to explore the pore structures of different catalysts. As demonstrated in Fig. 4(a ), Ni-Mg/HNTs prepared with the traditional impregnation method still presents the same typical IV isothermal curve as the support HNTs, accompanied by a H3-type hysteresis loop, indicating the existence of wedge or slit pores [44]. However, the Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts prepared by the sol-gel method demonstrate a H2-type hysteresis loop, which may be induced by the space between highly dispersed particles [28]. As presented in Table 1, the specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore size of Ni-Mg/HNTs have decreased after loading metal, likely owing to the blocking effect of some metal particles [45]. However, when utilizing the sol-gel method to prepare the catalysts, the small metal particles can enter into the support pores and create additional space between the particles. Furthermore, the removal of citric acid during the calcination process can also provide part of pores. As a result, Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts have a substantially higher specific surface area. According to the pore size distribution diagram Fig. 4(b), the pores between 20 and 40 nm are considerably reduced in the Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts, whereas a large number of pores appear between 5 and 20 nm. Notably, the specific surface area of Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.5 CA exhibits a slight decrease compared to that of Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA, likely attributed to the larger size of Ni particles. The morphology of the reduced catalysts and the dispersion of metal particles on the surface were examined through TEM characterization. According to the HRTEM images (Fig. S1), the lattice fringe with a spacing of 0.202 nm is indicative of Ni (111) crystal facets. And the lattice fringe with a spacing of 0.240 nm corresponding to NiO (111) or MgO (111) crystal facets can also be observed in all the catalysts, which is consistent with the XRD findings. As depicted in Fig. 5 , the metal particles in the catalysts prepared through a simple sol-gel method (Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA) are highly distributed in contrast to the Ni-Mg/HNTs. The average size of metal particles (including Ni and metal oxides) decreases from the largest 12.6 nm (Ni-Mg/HNTs) to the smallest 5.6 nm (Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA). The too large molar ratio of citric acid/metal may release excess heat during the calcination process, resulting in the agglomeration of the active phase in the Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.5CA. Therefore, the metal particle size of Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.5 CA is slightly larger than that of Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0CA. Ni-Mg/HNTs and Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA were further characterized by EDS-mapping, and the images are shown in Fig. S2 and Fig. 5(e-k), respectively. In contrast to Ni-Mg/HNTs, the distribution of Ni element in Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA is extremely consistent with that of Al, Si, and O elements in the support, suggesting that the sol-gel method assisted with citric acid can make the metal particles uniformly distributed. 3.3 Reduction and surface properties of catalysts The fresh catalysts after calcination were utilized for H2-TPR characterization to explore the interaction between the metal and the support. It can be seen from Fig. 6 that Ni-Mg/HNTs demonstrates a low-temperature reduction peak at approximately 403°C and a high-temperature reduction peak around 552°C. The former reduction peak can be attributed to the larger NiO particles with weak metal-support interactions [46], whereas the latter peak corresponds to highly dispersed small NiO particles exhibiting strong interactions with the support [47]. Interestingly, the intensity of the low-temperature reduction peak in Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts decreases dramatically. And there is mainly a broad reduction peak appearing in the high-temperature range, implying that the metal particles in Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts are uniformly dispersed. What's more, the reduction peaks of Ni-Mg/HNTs-0.5CA, Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA, and Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.5CA mainly appear around 544°C, 576°C, and 573°C respectively, indicating that employing an appropriate amount of citric acid to prepare the catalyst is beneficial to enhance the metal-support interaction. The COO− in the citric acid can firmly chelate the metal ions through chemical interactions, preventing them from interacting with each other. These citric acid-metal complexes then crosslink to form a three-dimensional network structure, enabling the stable and uniform dispersion of metal particles on the catalyst surface. The ability of the catalyst for CO2 activation and H2 dissociation is crucial in CO2 methanation, typically associated with the catalyst's activity and selectivity. The basic properties of the catalysts after reduction were investigated by CO2-TPD characterization Fig. 7(a ). It can be found that CO2 desorption peaks of all catalysts are primarily distributed across three temperature ranges. Among them, the peaks with temperatures less than 150°C (α) can be attributed to the weak basic sites (OH−) [48], and the desorption peak between 150 and 400°C (β) can be regarded as the medium-strong basic sites (metal-O2− pairs) [49]. While the desorption peaks with temperatures above 400°C (γ) can be considered as the strong basic sites (O2− sites) [50]. Based on the literature [51], CO2 adsorbed on the weak basic sites can generate bicarbonate species, which can further react with activated H atoms to generate the product CH4. Additionally, the medium-strong basic sites can promote the formation of bidentate formates, which are more easily hydrogenated to generate CH4 in contrast to the monodentate formates [20]. However, the intermediate species adsorbed on the strong basic sites are challenging to desorb, thus impeding the further hydrogenation of CO2 [12]. The distribution of basic sites on the catalyst surface was further analyzed, as presented in Table 2 . In comparison to Ni-Mg/HNTs, Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts have more weak and medium-strong basic sites. Importantly, the content of weak and medium-strong basic sites in Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0CA is significantly higher than other catalysts. This may be because metal particles are highly dispersed in the catalysts, leading to generating more Ni-O2− pairs. Therefore, Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA provides an adequate number of effective basic sites for CO2 adsorption and activation, resulting in enhanced catalytic efficiency. The H2 dissociation capability of different catalysts was further analyzed through H2-TPD experiments Fig. 7(b). The desorption peaks of H2 are primarily observed in two temperature regions: a high-temperature region I (<300°C) and a high-temperature region II (>300°C). The peak centered at low-temperature can be considered as the hydrogen desorbed from the small Ni particles, whereas the high-temperature desorption peak is likely due to the hydrogen strongly adsorbed by the Ni subsurface layer or the hydrogen spillover effect [19,52]. Compared to Ni-Mg/HNTs, the desorption peak area and the temperature in the low-temperature region (<300°C) of Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts have increased, indicating more small Ni particles and the enhanced interaction between H2 and the catalyst. This is beneficial for Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts to dissociate H2, as evidenced by H2-TPD results (Table 3 ). In comparison to Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA, the hydrogen amount desorbed by Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.5 CA has reduced owing to the larger Ni particles covering part of the active sites. The chemical environment of Ni and O elements on the catalyst surface was determined by XPS characterization, with the deconvolution results summarized in Table 4 . The Ni 2p spectrum can be divided into three regions Fig. 8(a ). The peaks at a binding energy of 852.8 eV can be identified as Ni0 sites, and the peaks appearing around 855.5 and 872.8 eV can be attributed to Ni2+ [53]. Moreover, the satellite peaks associated with Ni2+ are detected at binding energies of 861.3 and 879.3 eV [54]. The presence of Ni2+ on the catalyst surface may be due to the non-in-situ operation of the XPS experiment in this study and the existence of irreducible NiO species. More importantly, smaller Ni particles exhibit greater reactivity and are more prone to rapid oxidation when exposed to air [47]. The order of Ni2+ content of different catalysts is as follows: Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA (93.2%) > Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.5 CA (92.2%) > Ni-Mg/HNTs-0.5 CA (90.2%) > Ni-Mg /HNTs (88.9%), implying that Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA has more active and smaller Ni particles, which is beneficial for enhancing the catalytic performance. Additionally, it has been reported that Ni and NiO can activate H2 and CO2 respectively during the CO2 methanation reaction. Therefore, the catalyst with an appropriate molar ratio of Ni0/Ni2+ and the prominent synergistic effect on Ni-NiO can promote the catalytic activity. However, the existence of NiO and its role in the reaction need to be further confirmed and studied. As demonstrated in Fig. 8b, the O 1s spectra of all catalysts exhibit two distinct peaks. The peak with a low binding energy of 530.0-531.0 eV can be ascribed to the lattice oxygen (Oα) in the support (Fig. S3) [20]. Another peak with a high binding energy located around 532.0 eV can be attributed to the surface-adsorbed oxygen species (Oβ), which may originate from surface hydroxyl groups, the transformation of adsorbed O2 molecules, defective oxides and CO3 2− [7]. The surface-adsorbed oxygen species may be closely related to the catalytic performance because they represent surface adsorbates containing CO2 [55]. What's more, in comparison to the Ni-Mg/HNTs, the lattice oxygen peak of Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts shifts toward a lower binding energy, indicating the presence of oxygen vacancies [56]. As listed in Table 4, the content of surface-adsorbed oxygen species in the Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA (56.1%) is much higher than that of other catalysts, which provides enough active sites for CO2 activation, consistent with the results of CO2-TPD. Therefore, Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA exhibits more excellent low-temperature activity in CO2 methanation. 3.4 Catalyst performance The evaluation results of catalyst activity are shown in Fig. 9 . As the temperature increases, the CO2 conversion of all catalysts first increases and then stabilizes. The complete conversion of chemically stable CO2 to CH4 is an eight-electron process that is hindered by kinetic constraints. As a result, CO2 methanation typically occurs at elevated temperatures. The CO2 conversion and CH4 selectivity of Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts at low temperatures (200-275°C) are higher than that of Ni-Mg/HNTs, suggesting that sol-gel method supplemented with citric acid can effectively enhance the catalytic activity at low temperatures. Furthermore, CO2 conversion of Ni-Mg/HNTs-xCA catalysts exhibits a trend of first increase followed by a decrease with increasing molar ratio of citric acid/metal ions. Among them, Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA demonstrates the best low-temperature activity with CO2 conversion of 55.9% and 88.5% at 250°C and 275°C, respectively. This may be because the uniformly distributed small-sized Ni particles enhance the ability to dissociate H2, and enough effective basic sites are beneficial to CO2 adsorption and activation. The synergistic effect between H2 dissociation and CO2 activation makes Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA possess superior low-temperature activity. In contrast, the excessive citric acid causes the precursor of Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.5 CA to release too much heat during calcination, resulting in active phase agglomeration. As a result, the reduced number of active sites prevents further enhancement in catalyst performance. The catalytic performance of various catalysts reported in the literature are summarized in Table S1. To investigate the influence of the sol-gel method on catalyst stability, Ni-Mg/HNTs and Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA were chosen for the stability tests performed at 325°C with a GHSV of 15,000 mL/g/h for 100 h. As displayed in Fig. 10 , the CO2 conversion of Ni-Mg/HNTs decreases from 98.5% to 90.4%, and the CH4 selectivity decreases from 100.0% to 97.7% after reaction for 100 h. However, Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA exhibits 98.9-93.9% CO2 conversion and 100.0-98.8% CH4 selectivity under the same reaction conditions, demonstrating better long-term stability. In order to investigate the cause of catalyst deactivation, the TG characterizations were carried out. As displayed in Fig. S4, no significant carbon deposition can be found in either Ni-Mg/HNTs or Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA, suggesting that carbon deposition is not the primary factor leading to the decrease in catalyst activity. The Ni particle size of the spent catalysts was further examined through XRD characterization Fig. 10(c). Following continuous reaction for 100 h, the Ni particle size in Ni-Mg/HNTs increases from 11.2 nm to 12.7nm, whereas Ni particles in Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA just increase from 5.7 nm to 6.0 nm, indicating better anti-sintering properties. This may be because the metal-support interaction in the catalysts prepared by the sol-gel method assisted with citric acid is significantly enhanced, which can inhibit Ni particles from agglomerating and sintering at high temperatures. 3.5 In-situ DRIFTS and reaction mechanism The evolution of reaction intermediates on the catalyst surface was observed through in-situ DRIFTS characterization, and the reaction mechanism for CO2 methanation was also proposed. For the Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0CA Fig. 11(a ), the infrared peaks attributed to hydroxyl groups (3760-3540 cm−1), bicarbonate species (1641 cm−1), bidentate carbonates (1439 and 1546 cm−1), and monodentate carbonates (1385 cm−1) can be found at 100°C, indicating that CO2 is successfully adsorbed and activated [1,16,57–58]. As the temperature increases, the peak intensity of monodentate carbonates continues to decrease, while the peak intensity of bidentate carbonates first increases and then decreases. This may be because the monodentate carbonates first transform into bidentate carbonates, and then bidentate carbonates continue to be hydrogenated. Interestingly, the bicarbonate species continues to decrease and eventually disappear with the increasing temperature. Furthermore, the bidentate formates (1357 and 1586 cm−1) [59] begin to appear at 225°C and increase with the rising of temperature. The formates have been widely recognized as one of the critical intermediates in CO2 methanation. Meanwhile, the small peak corresponding to linear-CO* (1832 cm−1) is also observed, arising from the decomposition of HCOO*. The CO* can be further converted to *CHO (1741 cm−1) and then hydrogenated to form methane [60]. Due to the rapid conversion, *CHO and linear-CO* are almost invisible on the surface of Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0CA [61,62]. Thus, formate and CO pathways can simultaneously occur on the Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0CA catalyst surface. A characteristic peak associated with the product methane exhibits around 3013 cm−1 [63] and the peaks near 2840 and 2892 cm−1 are related to the C-H stretching vibration of CHx [64,65], proving the successful formation of CH4. As shown in Fig. 11(b), the spectrum reveals the presence of bicarbonate species (1639 cm−1), bidentate carbonates (1437 cm−1), and monodentate carbonates (1380 and 1512 cm−1) on the surface of Ni-Mg/HNTs catalyst. Additionally, the characteristic peaks for bidentate formates (1356 and 1578 cm−1), *CHO (1461, 1742 cm−1), and linear-CO* (1840 cm−1) can also be detected, suggesting that the preparation method has no significant effect on the mechanism of CO2 methanation. However, due to the fewer basic sites and larger Ni particles in the Ni-Mg/HNTs, the activation and dissociation of reaction gases are more challenging. Thus, the concentration of carbonates and formates on the surface of Ni-Mg/HNTs is much lower than that of Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA. Notably, the limited H2 dissociation capability of Ni-Mg/HNTs restricts the participation of CO* in the hydrogenation process to form CH4. Therefore, there is more CO* on the Ni-Mg/HNTs catalysts surface. Based on the above analysis, the proposed reaction mechanism for CO2 methanation in this paper is depicted in Scheme 2 . First, CO2 is adsorbed and then reacted with hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface to form bicarbonate species (CO2* + OH* → HCO3*). Meanwhile, CO2 can be adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies to form carbonates (CO2* + O* → CO3*). H2 adsorbed on the Ni surface can dissociate into active H atoms (H2 (gas) → 2H*), which can rapidly diffuse through the hydrogen spillover effect. Then the dissociated H atoms react with bicarbonate to generate bidentate formate species (HCO3* + 2H* → HCOO* + H2O). Most formates are directly hydrogenated to form product methane (HCOO* + 4H* → OCH3* + H2O, OCH3* + 2H* → CH4* + OH*, CH4* → CH4 (gas)). A part of HCOO* can first decomposed into CO* (HCOO* → CO* + OH*) and then further hydrogenates to CH4 (CO* + 2H* → H2CO*, H2CO* + 2H* → CH3* + OH*, CH3* + 2H* + OH* → CH4* + H2O, CH4* → CH4 (gas)). 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of Ni-Mg bimetallic catalysts supported on the natural halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) were synthesized through a sol-gel method assisted with citric acid. Among these, Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0CA exhibited superior low-temperature activity, achieving CO2 conversion of 55.9% and 88.5% at 250°C and 275°C, respectively. Additionally, Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA exhibit better long-term ability over 100 hours of reaction. Compared with the traditional impregnation method, the citric acid-assisted sol-gel method can enhance the metal-support interaction, stabilizing metal particles on the catalyst surface, and thereby leading to the improved anti-sintering ability. The uniform dispersion of Ni particles on the catalyst surface exposes more active basic sites and Ni0 sites, facilitating CO2 activation and H2 dissociation and resulting in improved low-temperature activity. Furthermore, in-situ DRIFTS results demonstrate that Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA mainly follows both formate and CO pathways and the rapid transformation of intermediates causes superior catalytic performance at low-temperature. Herein, this work offers a rational design of active and stable catalysts for the low-temperature CO2 methanation with potential for industrial application. coredata.dc:description: Developing a stable and effective Ni-based catalyst for low-temperature CO2 methanation remains a significant challenge. This study presents the synthesis of a range of MgO-promoted Ni-based catalysts supported on natural halloysite nanotubes (HNTs) through a sol-gel method assisted by citric acid. At 275°C, Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA exhibits the highest CO2 conversion (88.5%) and CH4 selectivity (98.4%). The sufficient basic sites and Ni0 sites of Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0CA are beneficial for CO2 activation and H2 dissociation, leading to high activity at low temperatures. Additionally, Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA exhibits better anti-sintering ability during 100 h reaction, attributed to the increased interaction between metal and support. The in-situ DRIFTS results show that Ni-Mg/HNTs-1.0 CA mainly follows both formate and CO pathways, and the rapid transformation of intermediates causes superior catalytic performance. This work offers a rational design of stable and active catalysts for low-temperature CO2 methanation.
